verses.text: When the queen of Sheba heard of Solomon’s fame, she came to Jerusalem to test Solomon with hard questions. She brought a very large entourage, camels loaded with spices, much gold, and precious stones. When she came to Solomon, she discussed everything that was on her mind with him.
verses.comment: Modernizes 'came to prove Solomon with hard questions' to 'test Solomon with hard questions'.

verses.text: Solomon answered all her questions; there was nothing too difficult for Solomon to explain to her.
verses.comment: Keeps the plain meaning: all her questions answered.

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba saw Solomon’s wisdom, the palace he had built,
verses.comment: Lists what the queen observed.

verses.text: the food at his table, the seating of his officials, the service of his attendants and their clothing, his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings he made at the LORD’s temple—she was overwhelmed.
verses.comment: Preserves sequence of observations.

verses.text: She said to the king, "What I heard in my own country about your achievements and your wisdom was true.
verses.comment: Clear modern English, faithful to original.

verses.text: "But I did not believe what they said until I came and saw with my own eyes. Indeed, not even half of your great wisdom was told to me—you exceed what I heard.
verses.comment: Preserves 'not the half was told me'.

verses.text: How happy your people must be! How blessed your servants, who stand before you and hear your wisdom.
verses.comment: Modernizes wording but stays close to original.

verses.text: Blessed be the LORD your God, who has delighted in you and set you on his throne as king to rule for the LORD your God. Because your God loves Israel and wants them to last forever, he has made you king over them, to rule with justice and righteousness.
verses.comment: Brings out the phrase 'to do judgment and justice'.

verses.text: Then she gave the king a hundred and twenty talents of gold, a great amount of spices, and precious stones. Never had there been spices like those the queen of Sheba gave King Solomon.
verses.comment: Retains 'never such spice as' with clearer flow.

verses.text: Moreover, Huram’s servants and Solomon’s servants, who brought gold from Ophir, also brought algum wood and precious stones.
verses.comment: 'Algum wood' kept as traditional rendering.

verses.text: The king made steps for the house of the LORD and for the king’s palace from the algum wood, as well as harps and lyres for the singers. There had never been such things seen before in the land of Judah.
verses.comment: Clarifies purpose of wood as 'steps', not pillars (as in some translations).

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba everything she desired—whatever she asked for, in addition to what he had given her from his royal bounty. Then she turned and went to her own land with her attendants.
verses.comment: Explains that Solomon gave 'of his bounty', and that she returned.

verses.text: The weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred and sixty-six talents of gold,
verses.comment: Translation is literal, '666 talents'.

verses.text: not counting what came from the merchants and traders. All the kings of Arabia and the governors of the land also brought gold and silver to Solomon.
verses.comment: 'Arabia' is used as in most modern versions.

verses.text: King Solomon made two hundred large shields of hammered gold; six hundred shekels of hammered gold went into each shield.
verses.comment: 'Shekel' kept as ancient weight term.

verses.text: He also made three hundred small shields of hammered gold; each of these shields contained three hundred shekels of gold. The king put them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.comment: 'Small shields' for 'bucklers' for clarity.

verses.text: The king made a great throne covered with ivory and overlaid with pure gold.
verses.comment: Combines the description succinctly.

verses.text: The throne had six steps, and a footstool of gold attached to it. On each side of the seat were armrests, and two lions stood beside the armrests.
verses.comment: Note: Chronicles mentions footstool, Kings does not.

verses.text: Twelve lions stood on the six steps, one on either side of each step. Nothing like it had ever been made in any other kingdom.
verses.comment: Explicit 'either side of each step' for clarity.

verses.text: All King Solomon’s drinking vessels were made of gold, and all the vessels in the House of the Forest of Lebanon were pure gold; nothing was made of silver, for silver was considered of little value in Solomon’s days.
verses.comment: Paraphrases for readability, keeps original meaning.

verses.text: For the king’s ships went to Tarshish with Huram’s servants every three years, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
verses.comment: 'Apes and peacocks'—uses the usual rendering.

verses.text: So King Solomon became greater than all the kings of the earth in wealth and wisdom.
verses.comment: Keeps traditional structure.

verses.text: All the kings of the earth sought an audience with Solomon to hear the wisdom that God had put in his heart.
verses.comment: Clarifies they sought his audience.

verses.text: They brought gifts—articles of silver and gold, robes, weapons, spices, horses, and mules—year after year.
verses.comment: Lists gifts plainly; 'robes' instead of 'apparel'.

verses.text: Solomon had four thousand stalls for horses and chariots, and twelve thousand horses that he stationed in the chariot cities and with himself in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Follows Chronicles numbers: 4,000 stalls, not 1 Kings’ 1,400.

verses.text: He ruled over all the kings from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines and as far as the border of Egypt.
verses.comment: Chronicles’ version omits some details found in Kings.

verses.text: The king made silver as plentiful in Jerusalem as stones, and cedar as abundant as the sycamore trees in the foothills.
verses.comment: Adds 'foothills' for 'lowlands' (Shephelah).

verses.text: They imported horses for Solomon from Egypt and from every other country.
verses.comment: Summarizes horse import regions.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Solomon, from beginning to end, are written in the records of Nathan the prophet, and in the prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and in the visions of Iddo the seer concerning Jeroboam son of Nebat.
verses.comment: Chronicles sources listed differently than Kings.

verses.text: Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel for forty years.
verses.comment: Plain historical statement.

verses.text: Then Solomon died and was buried in the city of David, his father. His son Rehoboam succeeded him as king.
verses.comment: Text close to original, wording smoothed.
